O Thou!  who rul'st the Poet's soul,</br>And giv'st the varied verse to roll:</br>Thou, FANCY!  whose impassion'd strain</br>Calls forth the Muses' shadowy train;</br>When, in the intellectual hour,</br>The Bard exerts creative pow'r;</br>And, skill'd in all thy magick art,</br>He strikes the note that thrills the heart.

O FANCY!  source of transient joy,</br>Whose visions bless'd mine infant eye!</br>Ere yet I knew thy pow'r to name,</br>My conscious bosom felt thy flame;</br>O let thy glowing touch divine,</br>Inspirit, oft, the labour'd line:</br>And where the grace of Art shall fail,</br>Let Nature's hallow'd warmth prevail;</br>Oft animate with smiles the theme,</br>And paint as still I weave the dream.

And, lo!  the plains that FANCY loves;</br>Her forests brown, her twilight groves;</br>Where oft, at eve's still hour, the Muse</br>Her magick-colour'd vision views;</br>Or traces, oft, the Faery scene,</br>O'er mountains blue, thro' alleys green;</br>Or listens, in some vocal vale,</br>To wild notes fleeting in the gale;</br>Or, nigh some arbour's verd'rous wall,</br>Hears the dashing waters fall.

And oft I mark her vagrant way</br>With richer flame adorn the day;</br>As, with enthusiast hand profuse,</br>She scatters wild her burning hues,</br>And waves her sportive pinion bright,</br>And drops her many-tinted light.

What godlike Presence fills these shades!</br>What theme inspires the tuneful Maids!</br>O say, what more than usual flame,</br>In transport shakes the Poet's frame!</br>The visionary trains arise,</br>Seen but by quick poetick eyes;</br>The Forms that in the Muse's ray</br>Their orient-glitt'ring hues display!</br>The shadowy shapes now glance along,</br>And give to rapture all the song.

There shines a fane of beryl wall,</br>A mazy bow'r, an arched hall;</br>Where oft, reclin'd on margent green,</br>The wearied Knight to rest is seen.</br>But now the woods, with mellower light,</br>And softer splendours, charm the sight:</br>Pour'd sudden Cynthia's paler gleem</br>Twinkles on the haunted stream;</br>While Titania's pigmy train</br>Revel o'er the moonlight plain,</br>Where sylphs, and Gnomes, sweet sprites, are seen,</br>And dapper Elves, and Fairies sheen.

On the strange troop, the vision wild,</br>Delighted FANCY ever smil'd;</br>Where high, as Queen, she seem'd to ride,</br>In varying robe, and painted pride;</br>Touching her soul-enchanting shell,</br>With gentler fall, or louder swell.</br>The sullen cares, the kindred soul,</br>Awaken'd, feel her soft controul.</br>I trace thee, Goddess!  in thy flight;</br>Thy brilliant hues, thy stream of light!</br>While, issuing from thy haunted grove,</br>Thy chiefs in native splendour rove.</br>Immortal Bards!  O may I name</br>The few whom Genius gives to Fame!

O Muse!  reveal the source of Rhyme;</br>Revert thine eye thro' clouds of time,</br>When Sense first sought the pleasing sound,</br>And in harmonious chains was bound;</br>As o'er the tuneful ear was thrown,</br>A sprightly note, till then unknown!</br>As Bards unpolish'd lines rehearse,</br>While Musick aids the artless verse.</br>Ye holy Bards of Gaulic race,</br>From you the infant Rhyme I trace!

I hear their voice from Mona's cells;</br>I see them trace the mystick spells;</br>In each dark grove of sacred oak,</br>ANDATE fierce the priests invoke.</br>Now shouts of vic'try rend the skies,</br>And flames ascend with victims' cries!</br>Or, marshall'd on the bloody heath,</br>Furious they rush on glorious death;</br>Revive the drooping arm; elate,</br>Pursue the war, arrest the fate.</br>Their lyres the list'ning Passions hold,</br>And tame the fierce, and awe the bold!</br>Oft, waving high the mistletoe,</br>Their breasts with sacred ardours glow,</br>As the pale Regent of the night</br>Smiles on th' Enthusiast's mystick rite!</br>And, while the Bard, from hallow'd oak,</br>In Runick rhymes prophetick spoke,</br>All Nature felt — so fables tell—</br>The DRUID from his secret cell.

But, dearer to the Muse, the throng,</br>That touch'd the harp with varied song.</br>MINSTREL!  or TROUBADOUR!  or SCALD!</br>On whom the Muses fondly call'd,</br>Braiding their brows in joyous haste:</br>In genius strong, but rude in taste!</br>E'en COEUR DE LION grac'd your throng,</br>And BLONDELL gives to Fame your song.

Across your arm was thrown your harp,</br>Which oft you touch'd with accent sharp:</br>Enliven'd by the notes you strung,</br>You lightly danc'd, and sweetly sung.</br>Your merry rebecks, tabours loud,</br>Oft entranc'd th' astonish'd crowd;</br>And, as you pass'd the Gothick hall,</br>How grateful was the Baron's call!</br>With antick leap, and jest, and glee,</br>The castle echo'd merrily!</br>While many a tale, with tuneful sound,</br>His mighty cares in rapture drown'd.

O ye!  who with no frigid art,</br>E'er faintly touch'd th' awaken'd heart!</br>Unknown the Critick's formal laws,</br>Your native pow'rs extort applause;</br>While Dullness hears your wild-sweet strain,</br>Entranc'd, she drops her leaden chain!

While, on your slight, unpolish'd reed,</br>You breathe some old heroick deed;</br>Or, o'er some hapless lover's bier,</br>You raise the sigh, or drop the tear.</br>What tho' your rough, yet pleasing verse,</br>Would simple legends still rehearse;</br>And tho' we touch th' exhausted lyre,</br>With method, but with feebler fire;</br>Our polish'd toil, our artful strain,</br>Must yield to Nature's freer vein!

Parent of Verse!  O BARD divine!</br>Whom FANCY bids to lead the Nine!</br>Be this thy praise; nor weep thy rhyme,</br>That, mould'ring, feels the touch of Time.</br>Tho' Nature thine, our feebler art</br>May haply lend it's polish'd part:</br>Thus, Chaucer's thought, in Dryden's verse,</br>A race unborn shall oft rehearse.</br>So, when great Raphael's painting fades,</br>And Time the Student's hand upbraids;</br>The rival artists touch the place,</br>Renew the tint, and catch the grace.
In Woodstock's bow'rs, the Muse inspires</br>With pow'rful song Dan CHAUCER'S fires.</br>His notes entrance the ruder swains;</br>E'en GOWER and LYDGATE own the strains.

O mighty Master of the lyre!</br>The Graces, with the Muse, inspire</br>Thy early rhymes!  Well-pleas'd, thy shade</br>Shall view th' immortal wreath ne'er fade.</br>To melt or rouze the soul was thine,</br>As love or rage inspir'd the line.

Within a bow'r, to all unknown;</br>To all, but thee and Oberon;</br>Thou saw'st the mystick vision bright,</br>While Cynthia stream'd her silver light.</br>A choir of Dames who fill'd the green,</br>As stately march'd their Fairy Queen;</br>And lightly tripp'd the beauteous train,</br>While their rich robes swept o'er the plain</br>And, with the pomp, and dazzling rays,</br>The moon-light grove appear'd to blaze.</br>Then, as thou heard'st the sound of war,</br>And symphonies that play'd afar,</br>A gallant troop of warriors came,</br>Who long had worn the wreath of Fame:</br>With armour glorious to behold,</br>And lance that shone of solid gold;</br>With plumy casque, and burnish'd shield,</br>That gleam'd like lightning o'er the field;</br>On barbed steeds, whose proud array</br>The aweful pomp of war display.</br>A rival host, with spear and shield,</br>Call forth those knights, and claim the field.</br>His trump the herald blows; from far,</br>It flames the breast with ardent war.</br>And now the Tourney meet, and now</br>We seem to hear each shadowy blow.</br>Nor steed to steed, and knight to knight,</br>Now steed to steed, and knight to knight,</br>They mix, as thickens all the fight.</br>Here some, who joy'd the just to meet,</br>Dishors'd, oft sigh, and seek retreat;</br>And there the quiv'ring jav'lins glance,</br>Shatt'ring many a shining lance.</br>For oft, on him who seeks renown,</br>Ah, me!  shall wayward Fortune frown;</br>While, blindly, on the baser head,</br>Her meretricious wreath shall spread!

Tho' faint, alas!  my feebler vein,</br>Forgive, if thus I touch thy strain;</br>If, fond of Fancy's airy throng,</br>I dare the lengthen'd verse prolong:</br>Provencal FANCY warms thy themes,</br>And richly paints the Poet's dreams.

Thine, too, O FANCY'S fav'rite Son!</br>Thine, SPENSER, is an equal crown.</br>'Tis thine the Epick trump to hold,</br>'Midst val'rous knights, and champions bold:</br>Who strive for Fame's chivalrous meed,</br>With quiv'ring lance, and warlike steed;</br>Who, clad in gallant armour bright,</br>Or for the field or tourney dight;</br>Of gorgeous courts in peace the grace;</br>Defence in war; in both the praise.</br>Mark!  as they pass th' enchanted grove,</br>Bright in glory, wreath'd by Love!</br>Nor small thy fame for mystick tale;</br>The moral chaste, in modest veil.</br>Thus furious War, thus faithful Love,</br>Like streams, reflect the heaven above,</br>When o'er the varied landscape bright</br>The Sun revolves his heav'nly light.

With looks commercing with the skies,</br>Rapt in deep thought, see MILTON rise!</br>It's throne of fire, it's blissful state,</br>He saw — fell blind!  Nor dar'd unfold</br>What regions vast the mind shall hold,</br>When, with spread wings, she hath forsook</br>Her mansions in this fleshly nook:</br>The verse MILTONICK well may prove,</br>He listen'd to the GOD above:</br>And while we seem on Eden's plain,</br>We hear a Seraph's raptur'd strain;</br>So fair he paints the form of things;</br>And what he paints, so sweet he sings!

Mark the Landscape wide expand!</br>With piercing eye, and ardent hand,</br>Warm with life, and spirit free,</br>In Nature's walks the Poet see</br>Select whate'er the Muse enchants,</br>And give a charm that Nature wants.</br>Thro' hedge-row elms, in past'ral pleasure</br>Round the shady seats of Leisure,</br>We hear his milk-maid singing blythe,</br>And the mower whet his scythe.</br>Or does he build enchantments drear,</br>Where more is meant than meets the ear;</br>The gorgeous hall, the revel loud;</br>The quaffing God, the midnight crowd:</br>Or does, in plaintive numbers sweet,</br>His verse the hush'd attention meet;</br>As, floating on his wat'ry bier,</br>On Lycid' pours the classick tear!</br>To all the Poet can impart</br>The strength of Nature, grace of Art.

But view, descending on the plain,</br>In thunder, lightning, and in rain;</br>On winds that scowl the blasted heath,</br>Like Nature's universal death!</br>The Death-voic'd Owlet flits by day</br>Before the Witches' murky way:</br>Around the cauldron see them toil,</br>Intent the virtuous deed to foil!</br>Charming the air with witching sound,</br>Thrice they dance their mystick round!

From where the honied bee delights,</br>See ARIEL lead his loaded sprites.</br>From cowslip bells, a fairy dome;</br>From dewy blossom, fragrant home!</br>In hills, in standing lakes, in groves,</br>The Elves confess their tender loves.</br>In moony radiance as they meet,</br>O'er sands they trip with printless feet;</br>Or pluck the wings from butterflies,</br>To fan moon-beams from the sleeping eyes.</br>The Elf, the Hag, own SHAKESPEARE'S hand,</br>But scorn the pow'r of other wand!

Twin Imps!  or beauteous Stars of Fame!</br>BEAUMONT and FLETCHER add their name:</br>With milder radiance please our eyes;</br>Alternate set, alternate rise.</br>But when with SHAKESPEARE'S glorious Sun</br>In rival course they strive to run,</br>Their splendours sink, their glories hide,</br>In feebler fires, and meaner pride.

But now a race obtrusive shone,</br>Whom FANCY blush'd to call her own.</br>O say what mean this learned train,</br>These Bards of metaphysic vein!</br>Of nature void, as void of grace;</br>No passions know this scholar race.</br>Their woe no bosom e'er oppress'd;</br>Their love shall ne'er inflame the breast.</br>Who draw from books, and not the heart,</br>In vain shall boast the tuneful art.</br>Some strong hyperbole supplies</br>The Poet's bold sublimities.</br>Forsaking Reason, high they spring,</br>While wearied Fancy wants a wing:</br>And where the tender note should move</br>The soft complaint of gentle Love;</br>The Bard, perplex'd, with awkward Art,</br>Relies on mem'ry, not the heart.</br>Some Hermit cold aspires to write,</br>Whose frigid lays the Loves affright.

Ingenious DONNE, whose learned page,</br>Belov'd by ev'ry rhyming sage,</br>With harsher JONSON, led the way,</br>Till COWLEY clos'd the long array.</br>Postilion Nature mounts the horse,</br>And Coachman Art directs his course;</br>Conceits, as Footmen, run beside,</br>A glorious row of goodly pride!</br>And pleasant Truths, and useful Lyes,</br>In all their gaudy liveries.

Beneath a plaintain's shade, all day,</br>His careless limbs see WALLER lay!</br>Love winds the strings, improves his vein,</br>And list'ning deer have caught his pain:</br>But, while the shining laurels spread,</br>No am'rous myrtles deck his head;</br>And what, with SACHARISSA'S name,</br>He lost in love, he gain'd in fame.</br>A doubtful good!  a forceful choice!</br>Which most, does Love, or Fame, rejoice?

To various pow'rs of classick song,</br>To PRIOR'S labour'd themes belong:</br>Exhausted Art, with jealous smile,</br>Saw Nature crown the finish'd toil.</br>Here were not fits of heat and cold,</br>Severely just, and strongly bold;</br>Tho' sometimes o'er his lengthen'd strain</br>We languish, and of toil complain.</br>From him the youthful Bard shall learn</br>The ardent word and happy turn,</br>Catch from his nicely-labour'd line</br>The Poet's elegance divine.
Have ye not read, soft Maids of Love!</br>The banish'd Man, who woods must rove?</br>Have ye not felt his EMMA'S pain,</br>And mark'd her HENRY with disdain?

Ye lighter sons of Mirth and Ease,</br>Who live but to be pleas'd and please;</br>Oft, in convivial hour, ye hail</br>Of PAUL and HANS the jocund tale;</br>And oft research, with learned pain,</br>Where skulks the undiscover'd Brain.</br>The solemn sage shall oft attend</br>The Preacher's voice, and love the friend;</br>Shall hear his serious Muse explain,</br>That all we act, or think, is vain.</br>Let Science proud, with piercing eyes,</br>Explore the mine, inspect the skies;</br>Or, let the pow'r of Wealth be try'd,</br>The splendid luxe of golden Pride:</br>Let curious artists wait thy call,</br>And bend thy bow'r, and gild thy hall:</br>Yet know, that all our efforts vain</br>Augment our wretched lot of pain.

Laying by the hill's green side,</br>Where th' engirting waters glide,</br>Mark THOMSON round the varying year,</br>And ev'ry Season's scene, appear.</br>Rough Winter first the reign assumes,</br>Congenial horrors!  kindred glooms!</br>The virgin snows, himself as pure,</br>He treads, as solemn glooms obscure,</br>Thro' leafless groves, and icy ground;</br>Scarce frozen Echo yields a sound!

Lo!  from Heav'n's lucid chambers, Spring</br>Looks out, and smiles.  The caverns ring!</br>The minstrel choir renew their loves,</br>Touch'd by the passion of the groves,</br>That swell'd their breasts with genial fire,</br>Each feather shiv'ring with desire,</br>While in the warmer ray of Spring,</br>Oft  they wave the new-fledg'd wing.</br>Beside the brink of haunted streams,</br>In Summer, hid from fervent beams,</br>He feeds on Ecstacy the soul,</br>And darts a glance from pole to pole.</br>When bending Autumn gilds the plain,</br>And waves her glories round the swain;</br>He tunes the Dorick reed — As lave</br>The Nymphs, they listen in their cave.

Nor less thy Genius stands confess'd,</br>When LIBERTY inflames thy breast.</br>When Science, 'midst her train of arts,</br>From falling Rome in haste departs—</br>Tho' there her footsteps still we trace,</br>As beauties in an aged face—</br>Awake, lull'd Age!  there read thy doom,</br>As Lux'ry shakes this other Rome!

Lo!  more than tenfold night around!</br>Hark!  the death-bell's iron sound!</br>What mental spectres gleam along,</br>As rolls th' impetuous midnight song!</br>A taper shades the sable gloom,</br>The living Poet's groaning tomb.</br>The bell strikes one!  An aweful knell,</br>In Sorrow's cave who loudly dwell.</br>Behold, who dare!  the gates unfold,</br>The future fate, and Death, that hold!</br>Along whose gall'ries Terror's hands</br>Lift on high the flaming brands;</br>While sick'ning Hope turns pale with fear,</br>As Hell's loud shrieks invade her ear!</br>She falls!  she sinks!  the trembling air</br>Closes — and hides the dreadful WHERE!

But, when YOUNG paints Heav'n's blissful courts,</br>And to the virtuous deed exhorts;</br>The symphonies of choral skies,</br>From RAPHAEL'S golden lyre that rise,</br>And twice ten thousand gates thrown wide,</br>Bursting glories in a tide;</br>Enrapt I hear!  the Heav'n descry;</br>I hear — and, how I long to die!

Where wanton'd many a woodbine shade,</br>The plaintive HAMMOND, listless, laid.</br>Soft youth of Love!  he sweetly told</br>His fate, and Delia's bosom cold.</br>Full many a tender note was there,</br>Of pow'r to touch the soul of Care,</br>And draw adown the Fair-one's face</br>The tear of Love with mournful grace.</br>He never ask'd the Epick strain;</br>His Muse but sought one Maid to gain.</br>But she the train of Wealth requires,</br>And Love to act her low desires.</br>But Love detests the Miser's art,</br>And weeps the Maid of venal heart.</br>Ne'er slight, ye Fair!  the verse we sing,</br>Nor scorn the trifles Poets bring:</br>So shall your Name immortal live;</br>'Tis all the grateful Bard can give.

Hark!  COLLINS strikes the potent shell;</br>The Passions throng the magick cell!</br>And, as Madness rul'd the hour,</br>On the strings their soul they pour.</br>Timotheus erst so struck the lyre,</br>As Persia's Court did once admire.</br>Alas!  no Court may COLLINS tread;</br>The Bard by scanty pittance fed,</br>Ah!  see, the glorious Maniack dies!</br>Each heav'nly Muse, affrighted, flies!

But mightier in abstracted song,</br>His notes the Muses, pleas'd, prolong.</br>Ye vulgar, fly!  nor dare to view</br>What, Genius, is but meant for you.</br>O Muse!  refrain:  nor, rashly bold,</br>Do thou the mystick scene unfold,</br>Where all the shadowy tribes of mind,</br>In braided dance, their murmurs join'd.

See OTWAY touch, with tender art,</br>The secret springs that ope the heart:</br>Around their Bard the Muses moan,</br>And make MONIMIA'S woes their own.</br>With unregarded locks, wild spread,</br>The Fair oft beats her straw-clad bed.</br>Sweet child of Nature!  must thou feel</br>The woes thou couldst so well reveal?</br>Why faulters now thy tuneful tongue,</br>Where Nature's inspiration hung?</br>Steep'd in the bitter tear of woe,</br>That crust shall thy wish'd death bestow.</br>Let none thy life's cold mis'ry blame,</br>But drop the tear that gives thee fame.

And Him, on coal-black steed, who rode</br>The steep of Hela's dread abode;</br>And right against the Eastern gate,</br>Where Hell's nine portals rise in state:</br>There, while he trac'd the Runick rhyme,</br>The Maid prophetick rose sublime.</br>Or may my tongue, unfrozen, tell</br>Of Sisters Twelve, in rocky cell,</br>Whose arms horrifick hurl afar</br>The flames and thunderbolts of war;</br>And, as the paths of Fate they tread,</br>Eager heap the crimson'd dead!

But hark!  the Bard, whose magick lyre—</br>A Master's hand!  a Prophet's fire!—</br>Stops the Britons' long array,</br>Wildly scatt'ring dire dismay!</br>On Conway's frowning rock severe,</br>Affrightens hearts that doubted fear:</br>Till headlong from the mountain's heights,</br>With brother Bards his song unites.</br>The thousands shake, and deep their arms!—</br>Such erst the pow'r of Minstrels' charms!

What sadly-pensive Youth appears,</br>Whose ardent eye is dimm'd with tears!</br>Forlorn, with wild, distracted air,</br>And worn with many a vip'rous care?</br>Haste to thy kiste, thy dortoure bedde!</br>Thy glommed face, thy spirit dedde,</br>Thy cale-claie hande, thy visage wane,</br>I weep, with thee, ashrewed manne!</br>Tho' doubtful  be thy various name,</br>Not so the just applause of Fame.</br>Whoe'er thou art, sad FANCY'S tear</br>Shall frequent wet thy nameless bier;</br>Shall frequent, in a depth of gloom,</br>Adorn thy visionary tomb;</br>And grieve the more, in ev'ry strain,</br>Because she knows she grieves in vain;</br>While sighs from many a tuneful shade</br>The Maid's eternal sorrows aid.
And now the glitt'ring visions fade!</br>Some lights would break, but sink in shade,</br>On Death's cold tomb must flourish Fame;</br>AND HE MUST DIE, WHO ADDS HIS NAME!</br>
